usage.basic: Use these examples as templates for your own XP projects
usage.modify: Copy and modify the JSON files to match your team size, iteration length, and focus
usage.run: Pass the JSON file contents as inputs to the XP process

practiceGuidelines.pairProgramming: Essential for knowledge sharing and code quality. Start with 50% if new to pairing.
practiceGuidelines.tdd: Critical for maintaining quality and enabling refactoring. Write tests first, always.
practiceGuidelines.continuousIntegration: Commit multiple times per day. Fix broken builds immediately.
practiceGuidelines.refactoring: Continuous, not in phases. Keep tests passing.
practiceGuidelines.sustainablePace: 40-hour weeks. No heroics. Monitor team morale.
practiceGuidelines.collectiveOwnership: Anyone can work on any code. Rotate pairs to spread knowledge.
practiceGuidelines.simpleDesign: YAGNI - You Aren't Gonna Need It. Do the simplest thing that works.
practiceGuidelines.codingStandards: Agree on standards. Use automated formatting.
practiceGuidelines.planningGame: Business and developers plan together. Negotiate scope vs. time.
practiceGuidelines.systemMetaphor: Create shared understanding through simple metaphors.

teamSizeGuidelines.2-3: Small team - Intensive pairing, everyone knows everything, very tight feedback loops
teamSizeGuidelines.4-6: Optimal size - Good balance of collaboration and productivity, can split into 2-3 pairs
teamSizeGuidelines.7-10: Large team - Consider splitting into sub-teams, coordinate carefully, may need dedicated coach
teamSizeGuidelines.10+: Very large - Strongly consider splitting into multiple XP teams with clear boundaries

iterationLengthGuidelines.1 week: Short iterations - High overhead, very responsive to change, good for uncertain projects
iterationLengthGuidelines.2 weeks: Recommended - Good balance of planning overhead and flexibility, most common choice
iterationLengthGuidelines.3 weeks: Longer iterations - Lower overhead, less flexibility, good for stable requirements
iterationLengthGuidelines.4+ weeks: Not recommended - Defeats XP's fast feedback loops and adaptability

velocityGuidelines.firstIteration: Estimate conservatively. Team will establish baseline velocity.
velocityGuidelines.secondIteration: Start seeing patterns. Adjust planning based on actual velocity.
velocityGuidelines.thirdIteration: Velocity stabilizes. Can predict release timeline more accurately.
velocityGuidelines.ongoing: Velocity should be relatively stable. Large changes indicate impediments or scope changes.

tips: Start with practices that provide immediate value (TDD, CI, pair programming on complex code)
Don't try to adopt all 12 practices at once - build up over 2-3 iterations
Trust the velocity - don't pressure team to increase estimates
Keep stories small (completable in one iteration)
Rotate pairs frequently to spread knowledge
Refactor continuously, don't let technical debt accumulate
Celebrate and track team health - sustainable pace is critical
Include business representatives in planning and demos
Adapt practices to your context, but don't skip core practices (TDD, pairing, CI)
